file_content.text: Thanks for your assistance with the Chevin situation.
You're back--good! I just spoke with the representative's aide, and he'll be arriving on Dromund Kaas any time now.
I got Captain Guyvar's signal, too, but I haven't seen the Chevin yet. Everything went well, I assume?
You'll find the Chevin in good shape--fine representatives of their species.
Those workers will serve well.
You'll have to make do--the Chevin weren't in good shape.
The workers look bad.
They have been in the jungle awhile. I suppose we should have expected as much.
I think the representative will be pleasantly surprised.
It'll all work out.
Excellent. I'm glad we don't have to introduce the representative to some feeble assortment of slaves and old men. I'd be lucky to keep my life.
You have my money?
I have your payment right here--with a small bonus, in appreciation of your quick work.
We're preparing medicine and clothes to make the Chevin presentable. The aliens will give the representative the right impression, and the planet Vinsoth will support the Empire.
Are you sure the Chevin won't say something wrong?
No worries about the meeting?
Afterwards--what are you going to do with those workers?
What happens to the Chevin?
The Chevin will gain a new life in Kaas City if they cooperate, and an ugly fate if they refuse.
Time to go.
You've done good work. You've helped us create an ally today.
And when the Empire next goes to war, well... our allies will prove very useful. That is why the Diplomatic Service exists.
Get to the work camp as soon as you can. The representative from Vinsoth could arrive at any time.
You. Hold up a moment. Your Empire needs you.
My lord, my name is Major Bryson. Your skills are required in the name of the Imperial Diplomatic Service. Is this a problem?
My name is Major Bryson, and I'm requisitioning your skills in the name of the Imperial Diplomatic Service. I assume this isn't a problem?
If they're needed, I can put my skills to use.
No problem.
Good. I don't like to throw my weight around--it tends to sour negotiations--but there's no time for the usual channels.
Maybe, maybe not.
Have you cleared this through Imperial Intelligence?
Is this authorized?
Not exactly--but this won't interfere with your business, and I'd be grateful for help from your agency.
I don't answer to the Empire, "Major."
I'm not your flunky.
Then let me open negotiations. I'm not an unreasonable man, and the Diplomatic Service can compensate you well for your time.
Tremble when you speak to me, Imperial.
You dare to approach?
I am Sith. I am not to be "requisitioned."
You dare to approach?
Of course, my lord. I don't mean to step out of line--however, as I said, the Empire needs you.
Kaas City is receiving an important visitor soon: a dignitary from the planet Vinsoth. I need to prepare for his arrival, but my regular people can't handle the situation.
What situation are we talking about?
Situation?
I imagine you want this dignitary killed.
Let me guess: assassination?
Absolutely not. Strike that thought from your head.
Worthless bureaucrats.
Need I remind you that without the Diplomatic Service, the Empire would be at war with half the galaxy.
Dai Shovon is a Chevin--one of Vinsoth's natives. We consider his homeworld a potential ally, and we invited him to tour the Empire.
As part of his visit here, he wants to meet with Chevin living under Imperial rule and hear firsthand what life is like for his people.
So?
I didn't realize there were Chevin living on Dromund Kaas.
There are Chevin here?
Barely a handful. Most are slaves. Our best hope is to draw from the workers at a camp in the jungle.
Only the weak need to listen to others.
He can't decide for himself?
I never said he wasn't weak. However, the weak can still be useful.
The problem is this: Aside from a few slaves, the only Chevin we've managed to locate are at a work camp in the jungle.
We need to bring some of them here--get them cleaned up and presentable, make sure they say the right things. But the camp's been having troubles.
I see. And what troubles have you encountered?
Troubles, huh?
That's why you need a bounty hunter.
So you come to me.
That's what it comes down to. There are credits involved.
I haven't heard anything about a work camp.
This is news to me.
Tell me whose blood needs spilling.
Get to the violent part.
It all sounds delightfully treacherous.
Oh, fun.
If the camp is troubled, send in a squad of troopers.
The military can deal with it.
The military doesn't want to spare the men to go looking for "alien scum." You're better than a squad anyway.
The camp's in an area of the jungle crawling with beasts. The guards are holed up with the Chevin.
I need you to fight your way there. Clear a path. Talk to the camp commander, make sure he knows what we need--his strongest, healthiest Chevin workers.
How do we get the workers to Kaas City?
Then what?
These are people--you're treating them like livestock!
This is disgusting.
I'm treating them like aliens who haven't earned Imperial respect. There's no need to take personal offense.
I'm treating them like alien citizens of the Empire. What do you expect?
I don't think so.
This isn't some trivial power play! Those alien workers are the key to winning over the planet Vinsoth.
You'd better make sure this works, diplomat.
Be grateful for my help.
Just make sure those Chevin come back usable.
Fine.
When you arrive at the camp, deliver this case of supplies. The camp guards will need equipment to escort the Chevin here.
Good luck, now. Let's put on a show.
Not a chance. [Refuse quest]
Blast it all. Those Chevin at the camp are as good as dead, then. Now I'll have to order some off-planet slaves and hope it works....
I'm afraid I'm busy right now, but maybe we should talk later....
